review_title: Run as far from Gateway as you can get, or you will need counseling yourself!
pros: If you are in recovery or have a criminal record and have gotten yourself together, they'll hire you.  You can start with 0 CI hours. They are always hiring.  If you truly care about helping others, counseling offenders is rewarding.
cons: This company doesn't even deserve 1 star.  HR doesn't answer the phone, return calls or e-mails when you have questions.  Pay is low, despite the fact that they want individuals with degrees.  You get no sick days, so if you get sick or have an accident, you get written up.  Although they tout 18 days PTO time, you have to jump through hoops to use it, since they can't seem to keep enough staff.  The training consists of someone showing a counselor with 0 hours how to do things 2 or 3 times--that's it, but they write you up each time you make a mistake thereafter--they say you learn that way.  Policies & directives change daily, but if you voice any frustration, you are the problem.  Management is vindictive, dictatorial, evil, hateful, cliquish and can't get along with employees, TDCJ, or clients.  Management throws around the fact that she is on the ethics board as if it is a threat to keep everyone under her control.  If you dare to use common sense, show initiative, suggest a way to do things that actually makes sense, or even stand up to the games, vindictive character assassination, verbal abuse and constant drama, you are called unprofessional and get put on the dictator's hit list.  The environment is chaotic, and full of drama.  Don't be surprised if documents in your files mysteriously disappear.  They give employees bad weekly, monthly and annual reviews so they don't have to give raises. Nothing you do is ever good enough for management, but that's part of the game.  They don't pay anything, so they can't attract enough employees, but they brag about getting new contracts and PODs, although they don't have adequate staff to handle it.  They treat staff like crap, so they can't keep enough employees, but tell you to leave if you don’t like it.  Management is always saying that new counselors and practicum students are starting soon, but that hardly ever happens, so your caseload keeps growing.  The caseload alone requires you to work from the time you arrive until the time you leave--without breaks, but you must also run a department, which means even more work that has nothing to do with service coordination.
